												If I went by the reviews I'd not have gotten this game nor wasted any time playing it.  I got it on a Steam sale and it is worth full price.Sure there are flaws, acknowledged.    One of the levels stopped giving me hints and I got stuck.  Exiting the game and reloading (not reinstalling) it brought back that levels hints so I could proceed. BTW that particular map was a little different that it required some thought to figure out how to defeat the judge.But the game is FUN, not frustrating and I kept going even after sometimes dying a lot.THIS not the average shooter where the whole world is a free fire zone;  where any sighted  sprite or actor, is likely hostile, and you shoot it.In DREDD, indiscriminate killing  has bad consequences.  There are citizens that may appear suddenly in your face and , after years of computerized  "shooter training;" instinct is full-auto to THEIR face.  OOPs, reload save.  Even while blasting identified bad guys, one has to be careful of citizens, allied judges or the surrendered nearby.   --some actors are your allied judges.--some actors are criminal scum but can be disarmed / arrested (for me more satisfying than head splats)--the arrested /surrendered criminal scum are helpless and you have the moral obligation to avoid having them killed by errant gunfire; most likely coming from your own barrels.--some actors are citizens and you do not want to see them harmed, and in many cases you are trying to rescue them.--you can ambush criminal scum to gain a tactical advantage, but it counts against you.--you can challenge criminal scum and lose tactical advantage, though some will surrender; giving you the opportunity for that oh so satisfying arrest lingo ie "YOU JUST EARNED YOURSELF xxxxx Time IN THE CUBES."  And there is a level where you VISIT these cubes.   Jump off a catwalk on a container then into the iso cube, if curious.  A bunk, a toilet and print across the wall, CRIME DOES NOT PAY.  Unlike Fallout 3, your pockets are not deep.  You can only have two weapons which requires some decisions.   Firefights may use up your ammo of your preferred Judge Gun; and that's another thing, setting  criminal scum on fire with the incendiary round is inadvisable.  You overreaching cop, you. There are plenty of vampires and zombies to try it out on.   Your Judge Gun has all kinds of ammo types which replace gun variety in other games.  There is even some kind of grenade (I have yet to use).  Some levels you can go through Judge Gun ammo quick and there are other found weapons to try.  Once ammo is used up, these found weapons can get you through the level. Depending, although, on how things go, you may be trading them out for different found guns.  The grenade launcher may not be the best choice as blowback bites.   To save ammo, some adversaries can be tackled in melee mode with little risk.  Yes, health can run quite low and it may  require several save reloads to get through a level. The voice acting is hilarious, reminding me of Duke Nukem 3d, arresting a perp yields "tough cop" howlers such as  "throwing away the key," or "there's an iso cube with your name on it." or "you're taking the big ride;"  to name a few.  Tone quite close to the 2012  movie Dredd. Let's just forget about that Stallone attempt.  I think even Stallone wants to forget.The bizarre fashion world of Judge Dredd  can take some getting used to. For example, there are  numerous fatties with bellywheels to help prop their enormous bulk.   Apparently though, they are not an aberration as one might expect to see in a singularly unique character;  but a conscious citizen  lifestyle.  Wikipedia explained them  as "Bored citizens who have turned to gluttony as a means to pass the time."  Views  from rooftops and other outside areas can be breathtaking. Mega City One looms in the background, an architectural metropolis.  The skyline is packed with elaborate skyscrapers and futuristic aircraft ply the skies.  For a few minutes at least, I would take in that scenery marveling at its artistic skill.  I like to take a look around at the aesthetics of the environment and not just blow through the level.  There is a nightclub that had some interesting decor, for example.I'm playing this on an IMAC 27"  WIn8.1, bootcamp with an old USB Logitech gamepad not updated past WinXP  but it works fine on 8.1.  Like all other games,  I just have to re-import the profile after computer reboots and insure the profile is set to persistent (no there is no option to install the gamepad outside the program fldr).I'm sorry this game was not more popular, it has a lot of good things in it I'd like to see in other games; you do not have to kill the entire world to win.9/110A good look at what the game is about if you are still reluctant to give up the cheeseburger cash:http://superadventuresingaming.blogspot.com/2012/01/judge-dredd-dredd-vs-death-pc.html

												First off, let me get this out of the way : This game is objectively bad, but the following is why I think you should pick it up anyways.This game is an arcade shooter where the campaign is a means to unlock the more challenging ones. This game is based on the comic book dystopian future of Judge Dredd, where you play as the franchise' namesake Joseph Dredd. In this game's camaign, you fight through levels where you have to not only take down crooks by shooting their guns off or injuring them a bit before arresting them, you also have the dark Judges to contend with, as well as vampires. Exact plot details are lost on me as it gets really stupid. The game shows signs of brilliance and potential to be a great comic book video game franchise like the Batman Arkham series, but Rebellion ran out of money, and what we are left with is a 3 hour campaign that is pretty unpolished and unoptimized, even on more modern systems. And that's where a lot of the problems with this game come from, lack of budget and time. It doesn't have any great widescreen or FoV options, the enemy AI can sometimes glitch out and do stupid things. As such, I can understand how many could be put off by this game.On the other hand, this is a budget shooter that costs less than a Cheeseburger combo at McDonalds. Not only that, there are plenty of arcade style challenges that are unlocked when playing through the campaign, and they are actually quite fun. For a budget shooter, this one has a surprising amount to offer in terms of replayability. Not to mention, Rebellion did put in the effort to try to make it feel like a Judge Dredd game. If you are bored and are looking for something quick and inexpensive to chew through, you can definitely do worse than this game. If you are a fan of the series looking for something extra to add to your collected curios, this should at least amuse you.

												A violent FPS based on the famous comic book series from 2000 AD.The production value is somewhat poor. The graphics look very dated, the animations are jerky, the AI is stupid, the vampire and undead enemies are poorly coded and animated, the level design sometimes feels very obtuse, and there's a plethora of weird bugs.However, if you're a fan of the comic book, there's certainly fun to be had here. Rebellion nailed perfectly Judge Dredd's unique sense of humour and the rendition of Mega-City One is spot on. It's violent, gore, stupid, hilarious at times, and pure mindless fun.The headshots are awesome (instant bloody decapitation!). You can immolate people. Kill by ricochet. Fire homing bullets. And even reliably disarm perps by shooting their weapons off their hands, allowing you to arrest them, instead of killing them. You can also kill your allies and civilians. It's funny that you can abuse of your authority to arrest innocent civilians, while listening to their complaints make it all the more hilarious.Aside from the solo/coop campaign, there's a survival mode and many LAN multiplayer modes (you can replace humans with bots too). The multiplayer games, being fast and violent, can be very fun to play with a group of friends.

												Admittedly this game hasn't aged brilliantly... That being said it is a lot of fun to play, the shooting mechanics are solid and you are a non Dredd fan you might as well pick it up during a sale. also the low price makes it a perfect way to treat your friends at christmas without going out of pocket or resorting to buying bad rats. Now as a Judge Dredd fan I can say that in my opinion the Dredd universe is faithfuly represented, the storyline covers Dredd's general duties for example foiling bank robberies, arresting perps for low level crimes and generally applying the law to the means streets of Mega-City-1. The storyline also covers the more radical elements of Dredd's universe, the dark Judges escaping for example; this is the main plot point, hence the name Dredd Vs Death. Other threats Dredd will have to tackle are zombie and vampire infestations, dark cultists and the mad scientist Dr Icarus. If you are a fan of the comics you will likely notice many references to them in the game. The other part of the game aside from the main Dredd focused storyline is arcade mode, this pits the player in a challenge map pitted against infinitely respawning enemies usually with a time limit or number of kills that have to be reached as the win condition, although these aren't as fun as the main storyline they lightly reference the comics, such as playing as DeMarco P.I in one map. Overall I would say buy it if it's a sale and you want something to give your friends which is inexpensive, fun to play and most importantly, not bad rats. On a side note this is probably the most faithful recreation of the Dredd universe in video game.

												Judge Dredd vs Death is a first person shooter that gives me a huge nostalgic buzz when playing, this game was originally on the Sony Playstation 2 and I used to play this when I was a kid and had a blast!The PC version of this game really does show how dated this game actually is however with the poor graphical quality (Not even that good for the time it was made) it still looks passable and the unique Dredd dystopian aesthetic with the character assets and environments is somewhat pleasing still.I did encounter a few problems with this port; the resolutions are really funky and do not scale well with any display and gives weird resolutions like 2047 x 1894 which was odd, you also get the occasional flickering but I guess this is expected to come with a dated game. You do get AA options and AF options to increase the fidelty to polish away the jaggys.Is the game fun? YES, if you enjoy dumb shooters with quirky mechanics and hilarious at times early day ragdoll physics this game is for you, the npc's give off hilarious dialogue as you arrest them for stupid things such as 'Possession of a goldfish without a license'. There is also co op mode (Not sure about online functionality however split screen works.), and an arcade mode (Not sure about online functionality also) as well as a challenge mode which allows you to unlock cool cheat codes for the main story. As of the time of this review this game is on sale for £1.24 and I think it's pretty fun for an old solid fps with 3-4 hours (Not counting other modes) of classic gameplay. Just don't go into this expecting a triple A masterpiece, it's far from it.Edit: Split Screen apparently is non existant. Arcade mode is the challenge mode, and I think 'Battle' is the arcade mode with bots or multiplayer.

Intro & SummaryJudge Dredd: Dredd vs Death is like one of those B movies that's really bad and ugly, but intelligent and funny enough that it becomes a real masterpiece and great fun. It was also released back in the era of games like Postal and Carmageddon in a time when being unique was prized, and being crude and over the top wasn't a bad thing, so long as the gameplay was fun.Highlights* Great humour and satire, really tasteless and crude but smart, and funny* Fast pace, there's always action, or something funny happeningMistakesThe majority of this games problems come from it's total lack of budget and polishing, presumably due to rushing to meet deadlines. While the problems somewhat add to the appeal, and help make the price great value, they keep this from being a great FPS.* Probably too short. The price makes up for this, but it can still leave you hanging* Dated graphics and a lack of settings (FOV, etc) can cause problemsRecommendationsFor just £5.59/7.99€/$7.99 this is a very fair buy, albeit for a short playtime of just 4-5 hours. A great multiplayer and tons of characters also lend towards the good replay value. If this is on sale, pick it up. If it isn't, it's probably worth sticking on the wishlist if you have a sense of humour.

Perps" gametype.The campaign had a few frustrating parts, sure, and the jump physics feel a bit floaty, and the reloading animations seem to go in slow motion, but despite being rough around the edges, I felt that it delivered on its promise of making you feel like Judge Joseph Dredd himself, almost to the point of shouting "I AM THE LAW!" at your screen.

												Dredd vs Death is a short, dystopian fps where you go through the levels helping the citizens of mega city one until inevitablly you are sent somewhere else to help people and fight punks, cultists and undead until you eventually learn that 4 boss characters have escaped from prison and then you help the people where the boss characters went and beat the bosses, until you beat the final one, Death.The fps gameplay is mostly standard, you get to have 2 weapons maximum and you have to keep the pistol that all judges use. The judge pistol has several ammunition options such as explosive. flammble. and ricocheting options, but I found that they werent particularly useful or even detrimental; lighting people on fire didnt seem to do much damage and if they run towards you then you risk being burned. The high explosive mode doesn't have a huge radius for hitting enemies and most of the time its not worth the time required to change ammo from the normal ammunition. Additionally, on some levels you don’t get much of a refill on the judge pistol and usually have to rely on using an alternate weapon and these alternate pistol modes use your limited ammo faster. There is also some unneeded fluff such as  a reputation system where reputation increases when you arrest people and help citizens not get killed and decreases when you attack friendly targets and people who have already surrendered to be arrested; but this only matters for ratings unless you have the lowest reputation by killing friendlies, then the game will cause a mission failure. At some times there were bugs such as me sniping off some enemies that were set to be killed by a script and that caused a mission failure. Something that can get annoying at times is that its not clear where your next objective is, but the gameplay is fairly passable fps gameplay once you get past the bugs.The music in the game wasn't particularly memorable to me, but the dystopian setting and various advertisements for dubious fictional future products added to the atmosphere of the game. Given the short length and dated graphics in this game, I wouldn’t go out of my way to pick this up, but it was in a bundle and I got my copy from trading so I figured why not. Unless you really love the Dredd universe no matter the implementation, there are better games for your money.

												You know, it's kind of a shame this game exists and kind of not. On one hand it's a big bunch of lost and wasted potential which is really kinda sad but on the other hand it does a lot of things really good, speaking of its setting and all.But first things first: the story.Remember the movie? Yeah, neither do I, but what I do know is that the game's got nothing to do with it except for the fact that there's Judge Dredd in it. But since it originated from the comics it's fine.You are Judge Dredd, a badass cop in Mega City One who's trying to bring law, order and justice upon a chaotic world in which the line between crime and not-crime is blurred. The thing is: Some time ago the Dark Judges Judge Death, Fear, Fire and Mortis, who tried to kill everything in this city (they go by the motto "The crime is life, the sentence is death") were banished by Dredd and his associates but the local death cult of Mega City One now tries to free the Dark Judges and succeeds. Your quest is clear: Stop them at all costs.But what can I say, it's a short game. Once they're loose everything goes down pretty ♥♥♥♥ing quickly. I mean, really quickly. It's something like this: You're on patrol screwing up the bad guy's operations when suddenly: Problems at the Dark Judge containment facility. Then the Dark Judges escape, then there is a mission which completely unexpectedly leads you to the heart of the death cult of Mega City One, then you do some other♥♥♥♥♥♥and then come the last five missions where you are ordered to go to places where the Dark Judges try wreaking havoc. But I gotta say: the world fears 'em but srsly, the Dark Judges are weak. Three of them can't be killed by convential means, sure, but luckily there are conveniently placed things in each area that make defeating them possible. So all of the fights are pretty damn boring. Especially the last fight against Death. Because it wasn't even a fight. So the boss fights are terrible and in every sense hilariously awful.While we're at it: what about its gameplay?The gameplay of Judge Dredd: Dredd vs. Death is pretty much your standard FPS from that time. But it's got some unique features. The first one being the ability to arrest people. You know, the first couple of missions you are running through dark alleys and stuff with a lot of perps to arrest. So you shoot a bunch of guys until the others give up and then you arrest them. You can also kill them but that decreases your law-meter and hwen it reaches zero some other guys will hunt you down so you better don't do that. The arresting precedure has some kind of humour I must say. If you can read everything the perp is guilty of and how long the sentence will be. It's a pretty unique, if useless, feature but I liked it.Another feature is your main gun. It's not your standard issue pistol. With this thing, you can change ammunition types on the fly with the press of a button so that you can choose between several "shot types". For instance: Ricochet, explosive, incendiary, heat seeking or standard. It's a nice feature but also pretty much useless because I used the standard ammunition all the time anyway without even thinking about using something else.If I wanted to use something else I switched weapons. There are a couple of weapons in this game and you can carry two at all times. There aren't a lot of weapons, but there's some diversity. Two different pistols, two different shotguns, a machine gun, a sniper rifle which also can function as a light mg, a grenade launcher and a laser rifle which can also function as a sniper rifle. And you can hit people with your fist of course. And yeah, since it's a linear shooter, you can only have certain weapons in certain levels.Speaking of levels, let's talk about the modes in this game. There are two modes: Campaign mode and Arcade mode. The campaign mode is what you'd expect. A campaign with the story (that goes on for about maybe 4.5 hours tops) and all that. The arcade mode is different in that its missions are focused on mostly killing things (with the exception of the last few) and that it has nothing to do with the story whatsoever. In arcade mode, you initially have one mission out of twenty (I guess) unlocked and the missions unlock with progression through the main game. "Why is that?" you might ask. Well. Some arcade missions let you unlock cheats upon completion. The game developers wanted to make sure that you play through the game at least once before you can have each and every cheat.Each completion of a campaign or arcade mission grants you a rank of how well you did and either an arcade mission (campaign mode) or a cheat (arcade mode). Or it grants you a playable multiplayer model.Oh yeah, that's what I forgot. The multiplayer. Wanna know why I forgot it? Because the game's got no servers and multiplayer is virtually impossible via the internet. Just ignore that mode, you won't be able to play it anyway.Now, if we look at the game mechanics and♥♥♥♥♥♥there's really nothing new here that's outstandingly amazing and the enemy types are also not all that thrilling. But the game runs well on modern day systems (it should), it's got no bugs I would've spotted and it didn't crash a single time. That's an A+. Maybe. Sorta kinda.So, to wrap this up, let's look at the setting.And I wanna say it now because it's true: the setting is really cool and I love it. There aren't a lot of redeeming things about this game. But if there is one thing that I really liked it's the setting and the little bit of dialogue you can listen to while traversing through some areas. It's a dark, dystopic world which has a sense humour to it I really enjoy. Postal 2 was really great at conveying this humour to the player. If you wanna spot that humour on more occasions than the obvious dialogue in Judge Dredd: Dredd vs. Death you have to read between the lines. But still, it's great.It kinda shows in what world we might live a few decades from now. I had to laugh at lines like "Grot Pot: With a snack THIS delicious, who needs nutricial value? Warning: may cause death". Or "All terminal patients are to remain in their beds. I mean, what's the point?" upon a zombie apocalypse in a hospital. But that's not all. The NPCs you'll see and the areas which you will go through are awesomely designed. The big mega mall with tons of unhealthy food and other consumer goods and the rampant consumerism in that world which is conveyed to the player. Or the Smokatorium, a place for all nicotine addicts since public smoking is prohibited. And then the message "We are legally obligated to remind you that tobacco is very, very, very bad for your health. But that nicotine sure is a rush, huh?". The world and its design are great and this is where the wasted-potential-part comes in. With a setting this good the game devs could have made something better than this. But anyway. That about wraps it up. It's not a great game. If you think about it, the gameplay and story are pretty damn boring tbh. There aren't any game mechanics that are really "cool" so to speak. But the setting is really ♥♥♥♥ing great if you ask me. If it's cheap on sale I'd recommend you buy it. If it isn't on sale however you should spend your money on something more fun than this game. Still, I'll give it a "recommended".I myself played it because of its nostlagic value. Had a demo when I was a kid and now I found that game on Steam so I bought it during a sale. Was kinda worth it.

												Judge Dredd: Dredd vs Death is an Ego-Shooter from the year 2003. While the graphics of the game haven`t aged so well, the humor definitely has. The one liners of the protagonist are spot on and that you have the power to arrest people because they are too fat or don`t possess a goldfish license just has to put a smile on your face. A bit annoying is that the jump movement is broken and you will only jump every fifth time or so. Fortunately the game requires you only to jump three times over the whole game.Dredd has to restore law and order in various sectors of the city while he fights against zombies, vampires, criminals and the four dark judges of the apocalypse. The mission have a great variety of locations and each feels a little bit different. Besides the interesting story there is also a arcade mode, in which you have defend hostages and need to defeat waves of enemies. The multiplayer is kind of dead, but if you got some friends you can also play the whole game in a coop campaign. One of the biggest weaknesses of the game on the other hand is the length of the campaign, which only lasts about 4-5 hours. But this 4 hours are truly entertaining and gave me in every second the feeling to be Judge Dredd, the only who can the defeat the criminal scumbags. I AM THE LAW !Result: As a Dredd fan I really enjoyed the game, it captures the atmosphere very well and is quite entertaining as long as it lasts. But if you are not Dredd fan, don`t like old games and if it is not on sale you will maybe give this one a pass due to its short campaign. Everyone else should at least take a closer look and at sale it sure is a good choice.7/10

The storyline, despite being classic Dredd and with the Dark Judges, fails to truly hold my interest - the plot progression and game level objectives seem too separated and distinct from the main events unfolding and the results of success or failure are only visible as survive to the next level or game over.That's the negatives out of the way. If you're still reading, you might want to know that this game truly captures Judge Dredd, Mega City 1 (complete with fatties, scrawlers, Isocubes, Surfing and more) given the time of release and the technology employerd, the game does an excellent job of recreating the city environment faithfully to Bolland's artwork from the comics, and a typical cast of characters to boot.At the time of the game, Judge Hershey is CJ, Judge Anderson of course makes an appearance, but also there are the medics, Tek-Judges and mentions of the SJS (who investigate you if you don't uphold the law well enough). The voice-acting is hilarious and I am still unsure if this is intended or kitsch, but it certainly doesn't spoil the fun.Despite the short completion time for the main storyline singleplayer game, there are alternative gamemodes which promise a little extra replay value, and a multiplayer aspect, but unfortuantely, the internet multiplayer relied on GameSpy network and so is no longer functional, but if you have LAN connections you can play with others.

												Dredd vs Death is fun and even charming, but it's honestly pretty bad. The gameplay is...not great.Essentially, you have your lawgiver (with its many firing modes) and the ability to yell commands at citizens. See someone scrawling? You can run them down, force them to surrender and put them in the cubes for life. Dredd v Death’s gameplay is that it’s arcade based. You’re always being scored based how many enemies you kill, how many years you sentenced, and how long it took you to complete the mission. In order to get the best score, you cannot kill perps, you have to shoot the weapon out of their hands (or kill their leader unit) then go and individually arrest and sentence each one of them. This contributes to the tone of a Judge Dredd game, but it really ruins the pacing since you have to stop to give a dozen life sentences before moving onto the next dungeon. The other problem is the mass amount of escorting. There are only 11 levels and 4 of them have escort missions. When you realize that civilians are killed in 1-2 punches, you’ll understand why this is an issue.  Additionally, the difficulty curve here is incredibly steep.  Vampires, the most common undead enemy, take 5 armor piercing bullets to kill on Normal difficulty. They take 7-8 on hard. This is an issue because the lawgiver uses the same ammo bar for every kind of bullet.  More powerful bullets use more ammo. Additionally, more powerful ammo types have a lower rate of fire. What all this means is that on normal difficulty, you’ll quickly run out of bullets toward the end of the game. If you’re playing on hard…Grudd help you.Although the lawgiver has been lovingly recreated, there aren't a lot of opportunities to make use of it. You'll use standard and armor piercing 90% of the time. Ricohet is basically useless. You're often penalized for using hot shot. It can take 5-10 "high explosive" shots to kill a single enemy. I couldn't even find a single time to use the heat seeking ammo mode. Levels should have been designed to make use of these ammo modes. Instead, the levels are incredibly simplistic offices and hallways. The graphics are pretty bad (even for the time) and the city feels vacant, empty, and lifeless. The story… is also not great. Here it is: Dredd’s on patrol. Vampires show up. Vampires are taken to prison. Vampires break out of prison. Dark Judges break out of Prison. Dredd has to go capture them.   There are 11 levels in Dredd v Death. The Dark Judges don’t break out of prison until the end of the lengthy level 2.  Not only that, but one of the levels is just a boss fight, nothing more. So what is good? The humor. The humor is this game’s saving grace. You can arrest any citizen for insane trumped up charges such as littering or owning a gold fish. Almost every level includes a silly announcer to match the environment.

												I'd agree with most of the other reviews.  The more interesting aspects of the earlier levels, arresting perps for criminal offences in particular, are abandoned early on leaving 75% of the game as wandering round dark corridors killing legions of undead.  Dredd's Lawgiver is accurately reproduced from the comic strip although there's no role here for the Lawmaster bike.  Equally this is 95% "shoot 'em up".  There's no crime investigation, gathering clues, interrogating witnesses.  There's only the odd puzzle to break up the sort of non stop gun play last seen in "Desperado".  Also being Judge Dredd other than restocking ammo for or replacing your secondary weapon there's no role here for looting and upgrades.As with many games of this type the penultimate level is more difficult than the final level - primarily due to its length and limited medi kits.Like other reviewers I'd recommend getting the game in a sale where (with at least 50% off) you won't mind the relatively poor even for its time graphics and limited gameplay.Why the positive mark then ?  Well it is 2000 A.D.'s iconic Judge, weapons and characters are accurately imported from the original stories, and it's a competent first person shooter.That said the game that could be made now of the comic by a Bethseda, Rockstar, or Bioware could be awesome - more locations, more varied NPC interaction, some L.A. 												If you like FPS games and Judge Dredd and know how to not take things too seriously, this is a good game.  Personally, I love FPS games and Judge Dredd, so I had a blast playing through the campaign.  I'm not a nitpick every little detail Dredd fan, but I've got a couple of the "Case Files" books full of early Dredd comics and some other Dredd comics, so I know about Dredd and the world he comes from.Looks wise, it won't win any awards, not even by 2005 standards.  It's not photo realistic, nor do I think it's intended to be.  Since it's based on the comics, I think they were going for a comic look and they succeeded.  Still, it's not an ugly game.  It's got decent graphics and the recreation of Mega City One is pretty fantastic.  Plus, since it is from 2005, I'm able to play on nearly max settings and it looks really good on those settings.  The only thing I wasn't able to max was the AA (anti aliasing) because 8X won't work on my system, for some reason.  But, I got it working at 4X AA.Plot wise, it's pretty simple.  Obviously, you play as Judge Dredd, the super cop, prosecutor,  judge, jury and, if necessary, executioner of the future.  The story is simple, Judge Death and the other Dark Judges have escaped (again) and it's up to Dredd to hunt them all down.  The campaign takes you all over MC1 and even into the under city, old New York and to the Deadworld, home of the Dark Judges.  You fight street thugs, zombies, vampires, cultists and, of course, the Dark Judges themselves.  Mostly, it's run and gun, with fast paced action and levels.  I don't think any level took more than 30 minutes, the shortest was less than 10 minutes.  I have 7.2 hours in the game, but not all of that is in the campaign.  I've also played Arcade Mode some.  The array of weapons is nice.  Of course, you have the standard Justice Department sidearm, the Lawgiver, with its variety of ammunition.  You can also pick up secondary weapons.  There are other pistols, rifles, shotguns, machine guns, grenade launchers and even laser weapons.  One of the most fun aspects of the game is the ability to arrest and sentence people.  Some are enemies that surrender, others are people off the street that you sentence for whatever "crimes" they're committing.  Loitering, parking violations, possession of a hamster or goldfish without a license, smoking, whatever.  Also, if they talk back, you can add on 10-20 years for resisting arrest.  In some levels, I had over 3,000 years total sentences given out.  And, once the campaign is over, there's always Arcade Mode, which adds to the replayability.The game does have a few issues, which is why not taking things too seriously is necessary to enjoy it.  I understand there were some issues with development, so the campaign isn't what they were hoping it would be.  Still, it's fun if you take it with a grain of salt.  There are some AI bugs, like enemies that "fly away" after being shot.  But, that stuff is actually pretty funny, in my opinion.  None of it really makes the game unplayable, in my opinion.  If all of this doesn't have you already pushing "Add to Cart," wait for it to go on sale if it isn't already.  I got it on sale for a little over a dollar during the Black Friday sale, and it was money well spent.  Still, I'd say it's worth the asking price, but that's just me.

												In Dredd Vs Death, YOU ARE THE LAW! Prowl the streets of Mega City One as the cities greatest judge as you punch up and arrest perps and civilians, Lay down the law on Zombies and Vampires by blowing them way with your Lawgiver and dispense justice to the sinister Dark Judges, vile undead from another dimension that fully believe life itself is a crime and that the sentence is death.I'll say it up front, This game is really for fans of the Judge Dredd comic book seires as this little gem from the early 2000's can be described as very true to the source material. Meaning its NOT like the Sylvester Stallone movie from the 90's and it is NOT like the Karl Urban "Dredd" movie from a few years ago. Think of it a mix of both. Its cartoony and campy in some places while it still has a bit darkness to it. As a game on it's own there isnt really anything spectacular or innovative about it when it to the point that one can easily compare it to Halo: Combat Evolved that came out two years prior. The game runs well on PC and in terms of comparison the only things i can say about DvD that's really different than Halo would be the following:- The world itself (of course)- A points system where if you manage to obtain a high ranking after you complete a level you will be rewarded with extra game content such as new skins for multiplayer (which has a VS Bots mode if for whatever reason you wanted to play some Dredd pvp) and mini games a for a bit of extra new game plus.- The lack of vehicle use. There's not even a level where you can ride on Dredd's iconic Lawmaster bike.- Your primary weapon, "The Lawgiver" is going to be your main weapon in the game. While there are some other weapons availiable to you such as shotguns and grenade launchers, you will find  yourself using the Lawgiver alot more as it multiple firing modes (e.g. Rapid Fire & Incendiary rounds) are the best response to the varity of threats in the game.- And that you have bosses.The four bosses in the game, The Dark Judges: Fear, Fire, Mortis and their leader Death are not your regular boss battles, since they are undead they cannot be killed by traditional means and sometimes the boss fight requires you to do something different in order to win and to achive a higher rank at levels end. For example in order to defeat Judge Mortis at the hospital level with the most "brownie points" you will need to rescue all the hostages he has with him and yes they too can be killed at the slightest touch.In conclusion. This game as i mentioned is not for everyone except for those who either are fan of the comics this game is heavily based on and those who are looking fora cheap FPS to help pass the time. I recommend this game as the former but as the latter do not expect too much from this game.

ReviewJudge Dredd: Dredd vs. Death is one of the few classic gems that you can still play and get a laugh out of today. You don't have to have any past experience with the Dredd universe to play this game and have a great time. You are the Law!First ImpressionsAt first the game seems like any other "Run around and do this, while shooting random dude's in the process. That is, until you realise you have the power to arrest Anyone you see fit! Random dude taking a light? 5 years Iso-cubes! Random fat lady that requires a weelchair for her stomach to walk around? 10 years Iso-cubes for punlic obstruction! Needless to say you'll like the game right off the bat.Long TermWhile the hearing Dredd yell hilariouse remarks such as, "Your coming with me criminal scum!" And seeing Dredd's muppet face never really gets old. However, the game's story does get a bit dry after the first or second runthrough. Lucky for you there are a handful of survival modes for you to test your "Dredd"liness against! There is also a co-op and pvp mode for you to play with friends, although these both require portforwarding and it can be quite hard to find a server hosted by someone else.(Spoilers Ahead)The game starts you off with Dredd doing some basic training (since he is obviouslly new to the job). After which, you are called on missions to "Hunt down criminal scum!" During this mission, the Dark Judges escape from their storage (Why they keep these guys in storage, I have no idea). And who would have guessed that you are the only one that can stop them. So you now are traversing through metro-city trying to track down the Dark Judges, while also dealing with the chaos left in their wake. (Ps. There are there are random zombies, vampires, and cultists; don't ask) Once you have succesfully tracked down a Dark Judge, you then have to use their specific weakness to defeat them. (Sadlly bullets don't solve all the world's problems) To defeat the last ghost Judge, you have to travel to the dead-world, where he is draining the (And I'm not making this stuff up) "Psychic-energy" out of the Psy-judges. Which he then attempts to use to open a portal from the dead-world to metro-city. But of course, Dredd stops him while delivering amazing one liners like, "I'm not letting your manglly corpse into my city!" Then during the end scene, Dredd gets a lap dance from Judge Anderson. Until he gets a distress call about some crime in sector "Who frikin cares" and has to ride off on his bike into the sunset.OptimizationThe game has all the basic key bindings/game options, however the game does not normally support widescreen resolutions. There is however a mod you can download that fixes that problem, and as for running the game. You should be able to run this game, unless your computer is literally a potatoe with usb ports. ConclusionConsidering the fact that I got this on sale for less then a dollar, I have no regrets in buying it. However, I do reccomend waiting for it to be on such a sale before buying it again. I give the game a solid 6 Criminal Scum/10.

												Do you like slightly janky but otherwise well-intentioned games, with a surprisingly lavish and faithful interpretation of its license? Then you've played a Rebellion game before! Dredd vs. Death is like that, it's, like, a first-person shooter by Rebellion. But it's about Judge Dredd! It's also really darkly funny in a way I wouldn't have expected a videogame of Judge Dredd to be - the comics, of course, started as outright satire, so it's always refreshing to see a humorously inept and corrupt Judge Dredd. This is probably unsurprising - Rebellion actually owns 2000AD.It's not a fantastic game, or even a fantastic Judge Dredd game, when it comes down to brass tacks, but my oh my, if it isn't a bit of fun anyway. It's just so goddarn charming, so I can't say I don't recommend it to fans of 2000AD. If you have a fleeting relationship with Judge Dredd, you may find this is funny (and witty!) enough to lure you in. So, yeah. A tentative but heartfelt recommendation - why not.
